passage_text: The trumpeter swan (Cygnus buccinator) is a species of swan found in North America. The heaviest living bird native to North America, it also is on average, the largest extant species of waterfowl with a wingspan that may exceed 10 ft (3.0 m).

A big, beautiful, white bird. Snow-white trumpeter swans are a spectacular sight. With a wingspan of more than 7 feet and a height of about 4 feet, the trumpeter swan is the largest native waterfowl species in North America. Trumpeters have broad, flat bills with fine tooth-like notches along the edges.

They have a wingspan between 1.6 and 2 m (5.2 - 6.5 ft) and they weigh between 6 and 9 kgs (13 - 20 lbs). Their feathers are mainly black in colour but they have a line of white flight feathers on the edges of their wings.

The Trumpeter Swan (Cygnus buccinator) Wisconsin Status: removed from endangered species list in 2009 A big, beautiful, white bird Trumpeter look-alikes Trumpeter habits and habitats Swan history What you can do A big, beautiful, white bird Snow-white trumpeter swans are a spectacular sight. With a wingspan of more than 7 feet and a height of about 4 feet, the trumpeter swan is the largest native waterfowl species in North America. Trumpeters have broad, flat bills with fine tooth-like notches along the edges.

Both the male and female contribute to the nest building and the nest consist of grasses, weeds and reeds. The dimensions of the nest are approximately 1 - 1.5 m (3.3 - 4.9 ft) in diameter and up to 1 m (3.3 ft) in height. 4 - 7 greenish/white eggs are laid and they are incubated for 35 - 40 days by both of the parents. The cygnets are greyish/brown in colour with pale edging on their feathers.

Share to: There are many different species of swans found all over the world,  including Mute Swan, Trumpeter Swan, Tundra Swan, Black Swan,  Coscoroba Swan, and Whooper Swan.
